data.title: SELMA LAGERLÖF AND NELLY SACHS making history
data.meta_description: https://www.inverse.com/article/51639-nelly-sachs-google-doodle-backstory In 1909, Selma Lagerlöf became the first woman and the first Swedish writer to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature. data.text:
In 1909, Selma Lagerlöf became the first woman and the first Swedish writer to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature. The prize was awarded for her body

of work, including the 1891 novel To the Story of Gösta Berling and the 1902 two-volume work of fiction Jerusalem, the chronicle of Swedish peasants who migrated to Jerusalem. Selma was the preeminent Swedish writer of her day and produced an impressive body of work: thirty novels and four biographical narratives. She wasn’t content merely to be the most brilliant novelist of her age, however; she also worked extremely hard at obtaining the release of Jewish writer Nelly Sachs from a Nazi concentration camp. Sachs, inspired by her savior, won the Nobel Prize in Literature herself in 1966!

This excerpt is from The Book of Awesome Women Writers by Becca Anderson, which is available now through Amazon and Mango Media.
